title-group.article-title: Facebook Intervention to Connect Alaska Native People With Resources and Support to Quit Smoking: CAN Quit Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is some evidence that social media interventions can promote smoking cessation. This randomized controlled pilot study is the first to evaluate the feasibility and potential efficacy of a Facebook smoking cessation intervention among Alaska Native (AN) adults.

sec.title: Aims and Methods
sec.p: Recruitment and data collection occurred from December 2019 to March 2021. Participants were recruited statewide in Alaska using Facebook advertisements with a targeted sample of 60 enrolled. Participants were stratified by gender, age, and rural or urban residence and randomly assigned to receive referral resources on evidence-based cessation treatments (EBCTs) (control, n = 30) or these resources plus a 3-month, closed (private), culturally tailored, Facebook group (intervention, n = 31) that connected participants to EBCT resources and was moderated by two Alaska Native Trained Tobacco Specialists. Assessments were conducted online post-randomization at 1, 3, and 6 months. Outcomes were feasibility (recruitment, retention, and intervention engagement), self-reported use of EBCTs, and biochemically confirmed seven-day point-prevalence smoking abstinence.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of intervention participants, 90% engaged (eg posted, commented) more than once. Study retention was 57% at 6 months (no group differences). The proportion utilizing EBCTs was about double for intervention compared with the control group participants at 3 and 6 months. Smoking abstinence was higher for intervention than control participants at 3 months (6.5% vs. 0%, p = .16) but comparable at 6 months (6.4% vs. 6.7%, p = .97).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: While additional research is needed to promote long-term cessation, this pilot trial supports recruitment feasibility during the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, consumer uptake, and a signal for intervention efficacy on the uptake of cessation treatment and short-term smoking abstinence.

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: This study is the first evaluation of a social media intervention for smoking cessation among Indigenous people. We learned that statewide Facebook recruitment of AN adults who smoke was feasible and there was a signal for the efficacy of a Facebook intervention on the uptake of EBCT and short-term (3 months) biochemically verified smoking abstinence. Clinically, social media platforms may complement current care models by connecting AN individuals and others living in hard-to-reach communities to cessation treatment resources.

institution-wrap.institution: National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In Alaska, cigarette smoking prevalence among Alaska Native (AN) adults is 37% compared with 17% among non-Native adults.1 Alaska is the largest U.S. state and qualifies in its entirety for a federal designation of rural and frontier.2 Out of about 225 AN communities, 178 (80%) do not connect to a road system and are separated from regional hospitals by vast stretches of tundra, water, glaciers, and mountains.3 Weather and travel costs further impede smoking cessation treatment access and reach. The Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic accentuated the need for digital platforms connecting people to evidence-based cessation treatment (EBCT) resources.4 Social media tools are widely adopted globally,5,6 including by AN people,7 and are a potentially effective way to reach and engage individuals in smoking cessation efforts.

Thrul and colleagues8 reviewed 12 studies (2015–2018) examining the efficacy of social media interventions for smoking cessation. Nine studies utilized Facebook, and only three of the 12 studies were randomized controlled trials (RCTs).9–11 The authors concluded that social media interventions hold promise to help individuals quit, but additional RCTs are needed. A recent RCT compared two active Facebook interventions for smoking cessation12 and other trials are in progress.13 No studies globally have evaluated a social media intervention among Indigenous persons who smoke. In contrast to individual-based treatments, social media-formed networks for quitting smoking are consistent with the AN cultural value of interdependence, defined as relationship-oriented and collaborative.14

The CAN Quit study incorporated four phases to develop and then evaluate a moderated Facebook group intervention.15 The current pilot RCT evaluated its feasibility and efficacy for smoking cessation. We hypothesized the intervention would be feasible and demonstrate a signal for efficacy on the biochemically verified smoking abstinence rate at 3 and 6 months compared with the control condition.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The study received approval from the Alaska Area and Mayo Clinic Institutional Review Boards. The Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium (ANTHC) Board of Directors provided Tribal approval. The trial was registered with clinicaltrials.gov (NCT 03645941). Data collection took place from December 2019 to March 2021.

The CAN Quit study incorporated a community-based participatory approach into all facets of the research process as recommended by Lee and colleagues.16 We codeveloped the research questions and project with AN community members, and our research team included Indigenous persons. The ANTHC Research Consultation Committee, an existing advisory committee constituted of AN and American Indian individuals, provided feedback and advice on the implementation of all CAN Quit study phases. Study results were shared with participants via a mailed newsletter.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Based on recommendations for Stage I addictions behavioral treatment development,17 the targeted sample size of 60 participants was deemed sufficient for assessing feasibility. Although unable to detect statistically significant study group differences on smoking abstinence, the study can assess if there is a signal for efficacy and obtain estimates of the intervention effect toward planning a definitive Stage II efficacy trial.

We recruited AN adults who smoked statewide through paid Facebook advertisements geographically targeted to Alaska. Advertisements included an image of AN people with the text “CAN Quit. Research to Connect Alaska Native People to Quit Smoking. Looking for Alaska Native people who smoke to join a research study. Receive up to $175 for participating.” Participants were directed to call the toll-free number provided or to click on an embedded Web site link for more information. We screened candidates by phone to assess the study eligibility criteria. Inclusion criteria included: self-reported AN race or ethnicity, current Alaska residence, age ≥19 years old, smoked at least one cigarette per day during the past 7 days, cigarettes were the main nicotine or tobacco product used, considering or willing to make a quit attempt, had access to broadband (high speed) Internet, and either an existing Facebook account or would create one (for inclusiveness of new users recruited via word of mouth by someone on Facebook viewing the advertisement). Participants were excluded if they were enrolled in a cessation program or used cessation pharmacotherapy within the past 30 days. We offered smoking cessation resource information to ineligible individuals or those who are not interested in participating. We enrolled eligible participants who provided written informed consent by mail.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: The trial used a two-arm, parallel groups, randomized controlled design. Before the trial, the study statistician generated the random allocation sequence. Participants were randomized with 1:1 allocation to the intervention or control group, stratified by gender (men and women), age group (19–29, 30–49, and ≥50 years), and region (urban and rural); all considered potential variables related to outcomes.18–20 Rural residence included participants who lived outside of the municipality of Anchorage. Allocation to treatment conditions was unknown to study staff or investigators before assignment, and participants completed baseline measures before being informed of their study assignment. We administered survey measures for both study groups on the Web using the Qualtrics platform at baseline and 1, 3, and 6 months after randomization. Participants received a link by email to complete the online survey and were mailed a $25 cash gift card for each completed. At 1, 3, and 6 months, all participants were mailed a saliva specimen kit. We mailed participants an additional $25 cash gift card for each sample they returned by mail, for possible total remuneration of $175.

sec.title: Control Condition
sec.p: Participants received EBCT referral information by postal mail (printed materials) and e-mail. Information was provided about Alaska’s Tobacco Quitline including the availability of free coaching calls and nicotine replacement therapy (NRT). The study team developed a URL where participants could access contact information for their regional Tribal tobacco cessation treatment program, including a description of services offered (eg phone counseling and pharmacotherapy). Participants also received information on the National Cancer Institute’s free, population-level, smokefree.gov Web site resources. The Web site, tailored to all levels of readiness to quit smoking, includes a quitting guide, texting program, smartphone applications, online live chat, and URL and toll-free number (1-800-QUIT-NOW) for state quitlines. The control condition providing digital access to EBCT is consistent with that used in prior RCTs evaluating social media interventions for smoking cessation.11

sec.title: Intervention Condition
sec.p: Participants received the same EBCT referral information described above. Additionally, the novel intervention consisted of a moderated, secret (entirely private and non-searchable) Facebook group. The intervention duration was 3 months, consistent with other Facebook interventions for smoking cessation.11,12 The group began when there were 10 participants enrolled, the minimum number for optimal Facebook intervention engagement in prior work21 and ended when the last participant enrolled had access to the group for 3 months. Thus, as implemented, the number of months participants had access to the group ranged from 3 to 6 months (an average of 5 months). Moderators posted conversation starters, questions, polls on specific topics, and motivational messages with culturally specific images and videos from the content library and prompted participant comments and discussions every 2 to 3 days.

As described in detail elsewhere,22–24 our content development followed the approach used in the effective CDC Tips from Former Smokers educational mass-media campaign,25 including digital storytelling and connecting individuals to EBCT resources. EBCTs can double or triple a person’s chances of cessation compared to quitting without treatment26 but these are greatly underutilized.27 Tips features factual, graphic, emotional, and true stories told by former smokers to increase awareness of the harms of smoking and to encourage quitting. It recommends specific calls to action to use state quitlines and smokefree.gov Web site resources. Prior studies28 have noted that storytelling is culturally congruent to AN people, which made the Tips personal story format ideal for social media content development. We used the cultural variance and surface and deep structure frameworks29 to tailor intervention content for cultural relevance and perceived effectiveness. Selected Tips stories were included along with existing ANTHC videos featuring AN people, activities, and or values such as family and community.

sec.title: Content Library.
sec.p: We developed a content library (digital and written) similar to a conventional treatment manual for use by the moderators.24 It included: (1) welcome posts, group description and purpose, participant guidelines (ie informing participants about the policies for posting content), (2) options for Facebook group page cover photos, (3) 70 moderator posts: images, text, polls, and or videos that included a tagline to call the State Quitline and URL links for Tribal cessation program resources, (4) guidelines for handling inappropriate or misinformation (eg deleting unrelated or false posts), and (5) closing posts offering additional places to connect after the group ended.

We organized the moderator postings by topic and each included sample text the moderators could add to initiate discussion or modify according to current group conversations. Postings covered cessation topics including coping with stress, nicotine withdrawal, and cravings; personal health; AN culture and activities for quitting smoking (eg beadwork); quitting motivations (eg family) and preventing relapse; as well as COVID-19 prevention practices. The order of postings was not specified; moderators could choose posts based on the group conversations. Moderators posted for the entire group and responded to individual posts or queries.

sec.title: Moderators and Training.
sec.p: The moderators were two AN persons, trained by two trainers (CY and KR) in two phases.24 The training covered essential elements of online community management and moderator practices in part one and motivational interviewing, tailoring, and cultural adaptation in part two. The moderators actively participated in developing the training and intervention content, providing their expertise and background as AN certified Tobacco Treatment Specialists (TTS) working with AN persons. Moderators received ongoing coaching through observation of and feedback on moderation practices in situ.

sec.title: Sociodemographic Characteristics
sec.p: Baseline measures documented sociodemographics, health literacy,30 identification with Tribal tradition,19 subsistence lifestyle,31 and frequency of social media use32 information. We also assessed cigarettes smoked per day, time to first cigarette each day,33 readiness to quit using the contemplation ladder,34 and other nicotine and commercial tobacco product use.

sec.title: Recruitment.
sec.p: Recruitment data included the number of potential participants screened and eligible. We defined the participation rate as the proportion of eligible candidates screened who enrolled.

sec.title: Retention.
sec.p: We based study retention on the proportion of participants completing each follow-up survey.

sec.title: Intervention Engagement.
sec.p: The level of engagement by post was assessed using standard engagement metrics,35 obtained through Facebook analytics which reports the number of posts “seen by” group members, their reactions (likes, loves), and comments. We used these metrics to calculate engagement by participant, including each number of posts initiated (ie participant created a post with text, image, and or video), comments, reactions, and answered polls. We exported the text of participant-generated posts and comments into an Excel spreadsheet for analysis of content.

sec.title: Intervention Satisfaction.
sec.p: At 3 months, we used the 13-item Social Media Usability scale36 to assess participants’ satisfaction with the intervention including usefulness, ease of use, and willingness to recommend the intervention to others. The total score is the mean of all items, with potential range of one (low)-five (high) satisfaction. Using open-ended questions, we asked for feedback and suggestions on the intervention. At 6 months, we asked participants about their willingness to serve as a lay moderator for a future CAN Quit Facebook group, defined as someone who posts regularly and supports new members.

sec.title: Smoking Outcomes
sec.p: Our assessments did not distinguish commercial tobacco smoking from ceremonial or traditional use. Unlike other Indigenous populations,37 nicotine or tobacco products are not used in ceremonies by AN people in Alaska.28 Our cessation outcomes follow recent recommendations from the Society for Research on Nicotine and Tobacco workgroup that updated definitions and measurements of abstinence in clinical trials.38 Our focus concerning abstinence was on combustible cigarette smoking. At each follow-up assessment, we assessed self-reported abstinence from cigarette smoking for the last 7 days. We mailed a saliva kit with a collection tube and postage-paid return envelope to all participants regardless of self-reported abstinence. As part of the informed consent process, participants were told that the sample would be “analyzed for cotinine, a measure of the nicotine in your saliva.” We did not ensure that participants provided their own saliva samples. Participants mailed the specimen to research staff at Mayo Clinic where it was processed by their laboratory. We analyzed the test results only for individuals self-reporting smoking abstinence. As recommended, biochemically confirmed abstinence from smoking at each follow-up assessment was defined as self-reported abstinence during the past 7 days (not even a puff), with salivary cotinine level <15 ng/ml.38,39

At each follow-up, we assessed self-reported use of EBCTs including Alaska’s Tobacco Quitline, Tribal cessation programs, cessation assistance from a health care provider, NRT, and other stop-smoking medications. Follow-up assessments also documented cigarettes per day; quit attempts; and other nicotine or tobacco product use including electronic cigarettes, iq’mik (an AN homemade chewing tobacco),28 and commercial smokeless tobacco (ST).

sec.title: Statistical Methods
sec.p: To assess the adequacy of the randomization, we compared baseline characteristics between study groups using the two-sample rank-sum test for continuous and chi-square (exact) test for categorical variables. We used the chi-square test to compare retention rates between study groups. We used descriptive statistics (mean, median, and range) to summarize the level of intervention engagement overall and by select demographics (gender, age, and residence), as well as Social Media Usability scores. We identified common themes of response in the moderator and participant comments and participant-generated posts using content analysis.40 Two study team members (PS and CH) conducted the content analysis. We employed logistic regression to compare the proportion of participants with abstinence from smoking and any use of EBCT at each follow-up assessment. We analyzed data based on: (1) intent-to-treat analysis of all randomized participants, with participants missing data classified as smoking/no use of EBCT, and (2) complete case analysis of only participants completing the respective assessment. If participants self-reported smoking abstinence and use of NRT or other nicotine or tobacco product use with elevated cotinine concentration, they were classified as abstinent from smoking. All analyses used two-sided tests with p ≤ .05 denoting statistical significance.

sec.title: Recruitment
sec.p: Figure 1 illustrates the study flow. We recruited 127 persons during December 2019 through May 2020. Of the 127, 113 met the eligibility criteria of which 61 enrolled (study participation rate of 54%). All participants had an existing Facebook account. The age of participants ranged from 22 to 76, 62% were women, and 64% were rural dwellings. Study groups were comparable at baseline (Table 1).

caption.p: Baseline Characteristics by Study Group: CAN Quit Pilot Trial (N = 61)a

tr.td: High school or less than high school
Trade or technical/2-year or 4-year, masters, or doctoral degree
Health literacyd:“How often do you need or have someone else help you when you read instructions, pamphlets, or other written material from your doctor?”
Subsistence lifestyle:“What proportion of your food each year comes from hunting, fishing, and gathering (vs. store bought foods)?”
About half or more than half
Tribal identity“How much do you identify with your own Tribal tradition?”
A little or not at all

fn.p: Percentages are based on non-missing data.

Some response categories were collapsed (for education, marital status, health literacy, Tribal identity, and subsistence lifestyle) to suppress reporting numbers for cell sizes <5. This was done to protect participant confidentiality and minimize risk of exposing identities in this relatively small population.
p-Value from chi-square (Fisher’s exact test) or two-sample rank-sum test as appropriate
Other response options for marital status were married and partnered.
Other response options for health literacy were rarely, sometimes, often, and always.

Sum of nine items with possible score range of 9–36; higher scores indicate a greater frequency of social media use. If subjects missed any of the nine items assumed “less than once a day” (ie non-endorsement)
Single item with score range 0 = not ready to quit to 10 = I am ready to quit now.

sec.title: Retention
sec.p: Survey completion was 69% at 1 month, 69% at 3 months, and 57% at 6 months (Figure 1), with no significant differences detected between study groups. Attrition was due to losses to follow-up (unable to contact).

sec.title: Intervention Engagement
sec.p: A total of 128 posts were generated. Of these 78 were by moderators (61%) and 30 by participants (39%). Posts received 260 “likes,” 65 “loves,” and 545 comments overall. For each post, we summed the number of comments, reactions, and “seen by,” which was greater for participant-generated posts (median 25.5 and range 0–91) than for moderator-generated posts (median 19 and range 1–162).

Table 2 provides an overview of participant-level engagement including four categories (created a post, commented, reacted, and answered a poll) and total engagement count by select demographics. Overall, 97% engaged in some way at least once and 90% more than once. Participants generated a total of 313 comments with an average of 9.6 per participant (median 3 and range 0–129). Two participants made zero comments, six made one, 12 had 2–5, eight had 6–12, and the remaining three made 25, 48, and 129 comments, respectively. Women engaged more with the intervention compared to men, for example, median of four comments (range 0–129) versus two comments (range 0–10) (Table 2). Those aged 40 years or older had higher median levels of engagement across all four categories. There were no appreciable differences in engagement by residence (rural or urban) (Table 2), or by the number of months participants had access to the Facebook group (data not shown).

caption.p: Level of Intervention Engagement by Demographics (N = 31) Indicated by Median Number (Range) of Posts in Each Posting Type

tr.th: Number of times answered a poll
Total engagement (sum of all types of engagement)

fn.p: Participants created their own posts with text, image, and/or video.

sec.p: Seven primary themes were identified when analyzing conversations (comments) between the participants and moderators which focused on the need or importance of social support and quitting experiences (see Supplementary Table S1). Primary themes of the content of participant-generated posts also focused on aspects of the quitting experience and social support. Supplementary Figure S1 illustrates these themes by the number of times they were coded.

sec.title: Intervention Satisfaction
sec.p: The mean Social Media Usability score was 4.0 of a possible 5.0 (SD 0.7 and range 2.8–4.8). Open-ended responses from participants suggested ways to improve the moderator postings and overall intervention. Participants suggested moderators have additional and more frequent contact to interact and check-in with group members, and to include more stories and engaging activities (eg contests). Some suggested Facebook live events be added, such as a biweekly motivational speaker on smoking cessation. Seventy-one percent of participants indicated a willingness to serve as a lay moderator for a future CAN Quit Facebook group.

sec.title: Smoking Cessation and Use of Evidence-Based Treatment
Smoking Abstinence
sec.p: Based on an intent-to-treat analysis, the biochemically confirmed seven-day point prevalence smoking abstinence was similar for intervention and control group participants at 1 month (3.2% vs. 3.3% p = .98) but higher for the intervention group at 3 months (6.5% vs. 0.0% and p = .16), as shown in Table 3. At 6 months, the biochemically verified smoking abstinence was comparable for study groups (6.4% intervention vs. 6.7% control and p = .97). At each follow-up assessment, of participants self-reporting smoking abstinence, none reported use of other nicotine or tobacco products, and only two reported NRT use.

caption.p: Smoking Outcomes by Study Group: CAN Quit Pilot Trial (N = 61)

tr.td: Self-reported any use of any evidence-based cessation treatment

fn.p: OR, odds ratio; CI, confidence interval. Data are reported as n (%).
Complete case analysis included only participants completing the respective assessment. Intent-to-treat analysis included all randomized participants.
Referent for odds ratio is control group.
Logistic regression analysis with study group as the independent variable.

Among participants self-reporting cigarette smoking abstinence at 1, 3, or 6 months, none reported use of e-cigarettes, smokeless tobacco (ST), or other nicotine or tobacco products. At 3 months, two participants (both intervention group) who self-reported smoking abstinence reported nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) use.
At 3 months, these two intervention participants had elevated cotinine concentration but reported NRT use and were considered abstinent.

sec.p: Supplementary Table S2 shows results for exploratory smoking outcomes. We did not observe significant differences between study groups on the proportion of participants reporting a quit attempt. Cigarettes smoked per day declined in both study groups.

The number of participants reporting use of other nicotine or tobacco products was four at 1 month, three at 3 months, and none at 6 months. Of those indicating use at 1-month follow-up all reported other product use at baseline. Product types at baseline and 1 month were iq’mik at both timepoints (n = 1), iq’mik and ST at both timepoints (n = 1), ST at baseline and iq’mik at follow-up (n = 1), and ST and e-cigarettes at baseline and e-cigarettes at follow-up (n = 1). Of the three participants indicating other product use at 3 months, one reported use at baseline (iq’mik at both timepoints); and two did not use other products at baseline (1 used ST and 1 used e-cigarettes at follow-up).

sec.title: Use of EBCT
sec.p: The proportion of participants reporting the use of any cessation treatment was about double for the intervention compared with the control group at 3 and 6 months (see Table 3). Among all participants reporting treatment use, about half (54%) accessed Alaska’s Tobacco Quitline, 23% accessed a Tribal cessation program, 31% consulted with a health care provider, and 17% used cessation pharmacotherapy (some used more than one resource).

Among intervention participants, we explored post hoc the level of intervention engagement with smoking abstinence and utilization of EBCT. Of the three participants self-reporting smoking abstinence at 6 months, one commented 129 times (total engagements 161), the second commented 3 times (total engagements 9) and the other had no form of intervention engagement. At 6 months, the engagement level was higher for those accessing EBCT compared to those who did not (median of 10 comments and 27 total engagements vs. 2 comments and 7 total engagements).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This pilot trial found that statewide Facebook recruitment of AN persons who smoke was feasible and there was a signal for the efficacy of the Facebook intervention on the uptake of cessation treatment and short-term (3 months) biochemically verified smoking abstinence. However, group differences on cessation did not persist at 6 months. This research expands the evidence base of social media interventions for smoking cessation.8 Only four RCTs were previously reported, and our study is the first among Indigenous people in the United States or worldwide. We evaluated a new approach to reach AN people statewide using social media communication tools that are culturally relevant and already adopted. Prior interventions had limited reach to specific geographic locations in Alaska or AN populations.41,42 The research validates the use of social media advertising to recruit AN people statewide into research studies. The intervention was well specified in a content library that was developed using a rigorous, iterative process. Also, the trial was conducted using remote methods, enhancing inclusion (an AN cultural value), and generalizability.

We began recruitment for this study in December 2019, which unexpectedly coincided with the first known case of COVID-19 being identified globally. Despite commencing study recruitment during the initial spread of COVID-19, we exceeded our sample size goal using Facebook advertisements. Our recruitment efforts were successful in enrolling rural dwelling participants (64% of our sample), accentuating the potential reach of the intervention and extending support to those living in small, isolated Alaska communities. The study was well represented by participants of different ages (range 22 to 76 years). In the United States, Facebook use is consistent across age groups except for lower use among individuals ≥65 years.5 Only 38% of our participants were men, consistent with research indicating that women are more likely than men to use Facebook5 and participate in online communities to quit smoking.43 Unfortunately, Facebook usage data are not reported by AN or other Indigenous race or ethnicities,5 but prior surveys indicate high adoption of social media tools among AN7 and other Indigenous populations.44

We found high reported satisfaction with the Facebook intervention, and an adequate level of participation as defined by other social media intervention studies reporting the proportion of participants commenting at least once or more than once.9–11,21 We additionally summarized the proportion who created and reacted to posts as essential forms of intervention participation.45,46 Interestingly, women and participants 40 years of age or older engaged at a higher level than men and younger participants. Prior work found no gender or demographic differences with Facebook intervention participation.10,11,47 Future studies should confirm our findings with larger samples.

We examined only the inception phase of our online community for which, typically, moderator posts outnumber participant posts.48 Participant engagement level was higher when postings were made by participants compared with moderators, indicating the group was moving toward the establishment phase. Qualitative analysis of themes of participant-initiated posts and comments focused on the importance of social support and their quitting experience.

Promoting treatment utilization is an important issue for the nicotine research field,27 and we present novel preliminary data on the uptake of EBCTs associated with a social media intervention. We found the most common resources accessed were Alaska’s Tobacco Quitline, Tribal cessation programs, and health care providers. Those who used EBCT engaged with the Facebook intervention at a higher level than those who did not; this exploratory finding warrants examination in future trials.

We observed a signal for efficacy of the intervention on the biochemically verified smoking abstinence at 3 months (6.5% vs. 0% control condition) but not at 6 months (6.4% vs. 6.7%). The smoking abstinence outcomes and lack of longer-term efficacy are similar to those reported in prior RCTs.11,12 An RCT enrolling 500 young adults11 compared a Facebook intervention compared with a control group receiving smokefree.gov cessation resources and demonstrated significant differences at 3 months on the biochemically verified cessation rates (5.6% vs. 2.4%) but not at 6 (4.0% vs. 4.4%) or 12 months (4.4% vs. 6.8%). We observed no clear pattern of the level of intervention engagement among those reporting smoking abstinence at 6 months. Findings from prior research on this topic are mixed.10–12,43,46 We evaluated a standalone intervention to enhance its scale and dissemination and did not include live counselor contact, online cessation counseling, or provide NRT, as in prior studies.10–12,49

Our study has several limitations. Survey completion was only 57% at 6 months. In contrast, prior RCTs of social media interventions reported retention rates of 64%–73% at 6 months post-randomization9,11,12 However, data collection for these trials occurred before the COVID-19 pandemic. Although not evaluated, the pandemic may have presented health, social, and or other concerns limiting our participants’ time and ability to complete assessments as well as smoking cessation. Providing a greater incentive amount for assessment completion may have increased retention.12 As in other pilot trials, the study findings are limited by the small sample size. However, the magnitude of the difference in the use of EBCTs between study groups is encouraging and warrants examination in a definitive trial. Participants were AN people living in Alaska and recruited through Facebook advertisements. Therefore, findings may not apply to other geographic regions or Indigenous communities, and those who are not using Facebook. There were some delays in receiving saliva samples by mail likely exacerbated by the COVID pandemic, with an average of about 4 weeks (range 1–8) from distribution to receipt of the sample. The use of cotinine testing only to verify abstinence from cigarette smoking is limited when other nicotine or tobacco products or NRT are used.38 Expired-air carbon monoxide (CO) testing is thus recommended because CO is a combustion product and is not confounded by detection of their use. Thus, combining breath CO and cotinine measures is optimal. Overall, however, we found a low number of participants reporting other nicotine or tobacco product use, and no use among participants self-reporting smoking abstinence. We relied on the self-reported use of EBCTs and did not assess the duration or completion of treatments utilized. Facebook as an intervention platform has inherent limitations of the privacy of data obtained by Facebook such as when existing users click on, interact with (ie like or comment), or share recruitment advertisements with others.

Despite these limitations, our study demonstrates several strengths. A Facebook intervention has promise as a scalable intervention strategy to promote engagement in cessation treatment among AN people, especially those living in rural, remote, off-road communities, and this study points to new directions for research into how peer support through social media can promote long-term cessation in this population. Based on suggestions by our participants and supported in the literature,49 we plan to hold Facebook live events with Native Elder speakers, Tribal cessation program counselors, Alaska’s Tobacco Quitline coaches, and or health care providers to motivate and guide cessation. That more than 70% of our participants indicated an interest in moderating a Facebook cessation group was unexpected. Engaging AN persons as peer moderators to regularly post and support members could bolster intragroup support for quitting, and ultimately, enhance the sustainability of the intervention.50 Women engaged in the intervention at a higher level compared with men, suggesting that a women-only Facebook group may be advantageous.13 Our sample was comprised of existing Facebook users but other types of advertisements (eg radio) could be utilized to recruit new users to participate. Other social media platforms such as Instagram might appeal to younger participants.5,6 With larger samples, social network analyses could be conducted to better understand intragroup dynamics of social support as a mechanism of treatment efficacy. We intend to use remote and rapid biochemical testing methods (eg mouth swab test for cotinine and mobile phone-based CO collection) conducted proximal to obtaining self-reported data and documenting the sample collection and results by phone or video call or pictures sent by email.12 We also plan to obtain objective data on cessation treatment and apply the findings of this study in future research.

In conclusion, while the intervention did not promote increased quitting at 6 months, this pilot trial supports recruitment feasibility and a signal for intervention efficacy on the uptake of cessation treatment and short-term smoking abstinence. Clinically, results may be useful to providers, State Tobacco Quitlines, and Tribal cessation programs. Social media platforms may complement current care models by connecting AN individuals and others living in hard-to-reach communities to cessation treatment resources. Our community-based participatory approach to the development and evaluation of our social media intervention can serve as a framework for other Indigenous communities aiming to focus on commercial tobacco cessation.

sec.title: Supplementary Material
sec.p: A Contributorship Form detailing each author’s specific involvement with this content, as well as any supplementary data, are available online at https://academic.oup.com/ntr.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank the CAN Quit study participants. We appreciate the ANTHC Research Consultation Committee for guiding the development and implementation of this study. We also appreciate the contributions of Selma Oskolkoff-Simon, Fiona Brosnan, and Michael Doyle, ANTHC Marketing and Communication. We are grateful for the technical assistance provided by the Health Communications Branch of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. We thank the Mayo Clinic Survey Research Center for their assistance with the survey design and data collection. We also appreciate the contributions of Kimberly Kinnoin, Nicole Reinicke, and Jeremy Weis at Mayo Clinic.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) and the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) of the National Institutes of Health (R34 DA046008 and R34 DA046008-S1 to C.A.P.). The content is solely the responsibility of the authors and does not necessarily represent the official views of the National Institutes of Health. The funding source had no role in the study design; in the collection, analysis, and interpretation of data; in writing the manuscript; or in the decision to submit the article for publication.

sec.title: Declaration of Interests
sec.p: Unrelated to this project, Dr. Prochaska has provided consultation to pharmaceutical and technology companies that make medications and other treatments for quitting smoking and has received funding from Facebook for planning the evaluation of a mobile health intervention. Dr. Prochaska also has served as an expert witness in lawsuits against tobacco companies. All other authors have no conflicts of interest to disclose.

sec.title: Data Availability
sec.p: The data underlying this article cannot be shared publicly because research conducted with Alaska Native communities falls under the authority of Alaska Native regional health organizations and the Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium. Requests to share data can be made to the corresponding author but must be approved through the established Tribal review process.

sec.title: Clinical Trial Registration
sec.p: ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT 03645941; registered on August 24, 2018.
